content.webTitle: Nurseries 'could close' due to government's 30-hour free childcare plan

fields.headline: Nurseries 'could close' due to government's 30-hour free childcare plan
fields.bodyText: The government’s 30-hour free childcare offer has come under fire in a new report that claims almost half of early years providers fear they may be driven out of business as a result of the policy. The sector has been warning the government that the offer, while attractive to working parents, is under-resourced and will lead to a significant funding gap for many providers. The study, conducted by the Pre-school Learning Alliance – the largest early years membership organisation in England, found that 49% of providers who took part in their online survey said there was a risk that they could close as a result of the doubling of the free childcare offer for three and four-year-olds from 15 to 30 hours. Almost half (48%) said they would have to cut the number of places they offer to other age groups, and 50% did not feel confident they would have the capacity to meet demand for places. Of the 1,500 childcare providers who took part, 30% are planning to deliver the 30-hour offer; while 19% say they aren’t planning to, with just more than a half still undecided. Six out of 10 of them said they thought the new offer, which is due to be introduced next year, would have a negative financial impact on their business. Neil Leitch, the alliance’s chief executive, said: “These figures are a stark warning of what could happen if the government insists on rolling out an underfunded, under-resourced free entitlement offer.” He welcomed government plans to increase average early years funding rates, but said that with extra costs elsewhere, including the introduction of the “national living wage”, there would still be a funding gap for early years providers. “The Department for Education seems to be working on the assumption that the sector will simply fall in line and roll out the offer, whether or not the funding is there to support it – but it cannot expect providers to put the sustainability of their businesses at risk to fulfil a manifesto promise that they didn’t make and that wasn’t properly thought through in the first place,” Leitch said. “The fact that 98% of survey respondents currently deliver the 15-hour offer, but only 30% are definitely planning to deliver the 30-hour offer, speaks volumes.” Last month the National Audit Office warned that the education department faced a number of risks with its implementation of the new 30-hour entitlement, including concern from childcare providers about funding. MPs on the public accounts committee are expected to raise some of these issues when they question the department about the potential impact of the policy on Wednesday. A department spokesperson said the average funding rate paid to providers was being increased by an additional £300m a year. “Latest figures show 1.3 million children – the vast majority – are taking up the universal 15 hours offer,” they said. “With our plan to double the free childcare offer for working parents, we expect take-up numbers to rise. “That ambition is supported by the huge levels of interest in our early implementers scheme which will trial the 30-hour offer a year ahead of schedule in parts of the country with nearly 100 local authorities and 1,700 providers all asking to take part.”
